Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: An HOA inspection is scheduled and items left in the corridor could be cited for blocking an emergency exit.
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation2: A routine audit is scheduled far ahead, leaving ample time to update documentation
Story: I was heading out for work when I noticed Mrs. Patel’s old shoe rack still blocking the corridor. The HOA had sent out reminders about the inspection, warning that anything left in shared spaces could be cited for safety violations. As her neighbor, I knew she’d been struggling to move it, and I didn’t want to be the one to complain. But as an engineer, I couldn’t ignore the safety hazard—emergency exits had to be clear, no exceptions. At work, I’d never let something like this slide; I’d already started prepping for our own audit, even though it was months away. But here, in my own building, it felt different. I could hear Mrs. Patel’s television through her door, and I imagined her frustration if she got a violation notice. My mind raced between wanting to be a good neighbor—understanding, patient—and the ingrained responsibility to uphold safety standards. I stood in the hallway, keys in hand, torn between knocking on her door to gently remind her, reporting it anonymously, or just letting it go. The weight of both roles pressed on me, and I hesitated, caught between what I should do and what I wanted to do.
